sect1.title: Ripping audio CDs with Sound Juicer
sect1.para: Launch Sound Juicer from the Multimedia section of the applications menu. First, you should set where you want your music to be ripped to, so select Preferences from the Edit menu. Browse to the location of your stored music, or just create a new folder (~/music, for example), and select it for use. Close the Preferences window, and insert the audio CD you want to rip. If you have an Internet connection, Sound Juicer should fill in the information for the CD you inserted. Otherwise, edit the fields appropriately. Now, to rip and encode all the tracks, just click the Extract button. You can select tracks to rip using the check boxes to the left of each track, if you wish. You will be notified when all the tracks have been extracted, and given the option to eject the disc.
A more thorough explanation of the ins and outs of Sound Juicer can be found here.

sect1.title: Using the Music Player
sect1.para: Launch the Music Player from the Multimedia section of the applications menu. If this is your first time using the Music Player, a "Welcome to Rhythmbox" window will applicationear. Click Next to get started setting it up. It will prompt you for the location of your music library - if you haven't ripped any CDs yet using Sound Juicer, then you have the option to skip this step. Otherwise just click on Browse, browse to the location of your music library (~/music, if you went by my example) and click on forward to proceed. That's it - just click on applicationly to start browsing your music library.

listitem.para: Search for artists, albums or individual tracks using the Search box.
Narrow down the track listing by selecting individual artists and albums.

Listen to Internet radio - select Radio in the Source list, and choose from the available channels. Alternatively - if you have support for .mp3 installed - SHOUTcast is a good place to search for more. If you find a channel you like the sound of, then clicking on the 'Tune In!' link and agreeing to open the file in Rhythmbox should connect to the channel and start playing it immediately. (if anyone knows of an Ogg Vorbis alternative then replace the SHOUTcast reference with it)
